employment for a specific term. 21 

(2) For the purposes of this section, a contract for a specific term may contain a probationary 22 

period as provided for in 39-2-910 and may contain an automatic renewal clause that automatically renews the 23 

contract of employment for one or more successive terms." 24

parents; 14

residential address if different from that of the child's custodian; 16

parent; 18

income to the obligor; and 20

(b) the specific day or dates the payment is due; 1

or agency taking the enforcement action may consider the due process requirements for notice and service of 1

Section 19. Section 40-5-1031, MCA, is amended to read: 10 

"40-5-1031. Pleadings and accompanying documents. (1) In a proceeding under this part, a 11 

petitioner seeking to establish a support order, to determine parentage of a child, or to register and modify a 12 

support order of a tribunal of another state or a foreign country must file a petition. Unless otherwise ordered 13 

under 40-5-1032, the petition or accompanying documents must provide, so far as known, the name, residential 14 

address, and social security numbers of the obligor and the obligee or the parent and alleged parent and the 15 

name, sex, as defined in 1-1-201, residential address, social security number, and date of birth of each child for 16 

whose benefit support is sought or whose parentage is to be determined. Unless filed at the time of registration, 17 

the petition must be accompanied by a copy of any support order known to have been issued by another 18 

tribunal. The petition may include any other information that may assist in locating or identifying the respondent. 19 

(2) The petition must specify the relief sought. The petition and accompanying documents must 20 

conform substantially with the requirements imposed by the forms mandated by federal law for use in cases 21 

filed by a support enforcement agency." 22

Section 20. Section 41-5-103, MCA, is amended to read: 24 

"41-5-103. Definitions. As used in the Montana Youth Court Act, unless the context requires 25 

otherwise, the following definitions apply: 26 

(1) "Adult" means an individual who is 18 years of age or older. 27 

(2) "Agency" means any entity of state or local government authorized by law to be responsible for 28 



 
****   
68th Legislature 2023   SB 458.1 

 

 - 16 -  Authorized Print Version – SB 458  
 
 

the care or rehabilitation of youth. 1 

(3) "Assessment officer" means a person who is authorized by the court to provide initial intake 2 

and evaluation for a youth who appears to be in need of intervention or an alleged delinquent youth. 3 

(4) "Commit" means to transfer legal custody of a youth to the department or to the youth court. 4 

(5) "Conditional release" means the release of a youth from a correctional facility subject to the 5 

terms and conditions of the conditional release agreement provided for in 52-5-126. 6 

(6) (a) "Correctional facility" means a public secure residential facility or a private secure 7 

residential facility under contract with the department and operated to provide for the custody, treatment, 8 

training, and rehabilitation of: 9 

(i) formally adjudicated delinquent youth; 10 

(ii) convicted adult offenders or criminally convicted youth; or 11 

(iii) a combination of the populations described in subsections (6)(a)(i) and (6)(a)(ii) under 12 

conditions set by the department in rule. 13 

(b) The term does not include a state prison as defined in 53-30-101. 14 

(7) "Cost containment pool" means an account from which funds are allocated by the office of 15 

court administrator under 41-5-132 to a judicial district that exceeds its annual allocation for juvenile out-of-16 

home placements, programs, and services or to the department for costs incurred under 41-5-1504. 17 

(8) "Cost containment review panel" means the panel established in 41-5-131. 18 

(9) "Court", when used without further qualification, means the youth court of the district court. 19 

(10) "Criminally convicted youth" means a youth who has been convicted in a district court pursuant 20 

to 41-5-206. 21 

(11) (a) "Custodian" means a person, other than a parent or guardian, to whom legal custody of the 22 

youth has been given. 23 

(b) The term does not include a person who has only physical custody. 24 

(12) "Delinquent youth" means a youth who is adjudicated under formal proceedings under the 25 

Montana Youth Court Act as a youth: 26 

(a) who has committed an offense that, if committed by an adult, would constitute a criminal 27 

offense; 28 



 
****   
68th Legislature 2023   SB 458.1 

 

 - 17 -  Authorized Print Version – SB 458  
 
 

(b) who has been placed on probation as a delinquent youth and who has violated any condition of 1 

probation; or 2 

(c) who has violated the terms and conditions of the youth's conditional release agreement. 3 

(13) "Department" means the department of corrections provided for in 2-15-2301. 4 

(14) (a) "Department records" means information or data, either in written or electronic form, 5 

maintained by the department pertaining to youth who are committed under 41-5-1513(1)(b). 6 

(b) Department records do not include information provided by the department to the department 7 

of public health and human services' management information system or information maintained by the youth 8 

court through the office of court administrator. 9 

(15) "Detention" means the holding or temporary placement of a youth in the youth's home under 10 

home arrest or in a facility other than the youth's own home for: 11 

(a) the purpose of ensuring the continued custody of the youth at any time after the youth is taken 12 

into custody and before final disposition of the youth's case; 13 

(b) contempt of court or violation of a valid court order; or 14 

(c) violation of the terms and conditions of the youth's conditional release agreement. 15 

(16) "Detention facility" means a physically restricting facility designed to prevent a youth from 16 

departing at will. The term includes a youth detention facility, short-term detention center, and regional 17 

detention facility. 18 

(17) "Emergency placement" means placement of a youth in a youth care facility for less than 45 19 

days to protect the youth when there is no alternative placement available. 20 

(18) "Family" means the parents, guardians, legal custodians, and siblings or other youth with whom 21 

a youth ordinarily lives. 22 

(19) "Final disposition" means the implementation of a court order for the disposition or placement 23 

of a youth as provided in 41-5-1422, 41-5-1503, 41-5-1504, 41-5-1512, 41-5-1513, and 41-5-1522 through 41-24 

5-1525. 25 

(20) (a) "Formal youth court records" means information or data, either in written or electronic form, 26 

on file with the clerk of district court pertaining to a youth under the jurisdiction of the youth court and includes 27 

petitions, motions, other filed pleadings, court findings, verdicts, orders and decrees, and predispositional 28 



 
****   
68th Legislature 2023   SB 458.1 

 

 - 18 -  Authorized Print Version – SB 458  
 
 

studies. 1 

(b) The term does not include information provided by the youth court to the department of public 2 

health and human services' management information system. 3 

(21) "Foster home" means a private residence licensed by the department of public health and 4 

human services for placement of a youth. 5 

(22) "Guardian" means an adult: 6 

(a) who is responsible for a youth and has the reciprocal rights, duties, and responsibilities with the 7 

youth; and 8 

(b) whose status is created and defined by law. 9 

(23) "Habitual truancy" means recorded unexcused absences of 9 or more days or 54 or more parts 10 

of a day, whichever is less, in 1 school year. 11 

(24) (a) "Holdover" means a room, office, building, or other place approved by the board of crime 12 

control for the temporary detention and supervision of youth in a physically unrestricting setting for a period not 13 

to exceed 24 hours while the youth is awaiting a probable cause hearing, release, or transfer to an appropriate 14 

detention or shelter care facility. 15 

(b) The term does not include a jail. 16 

(25) (a) "Informal youth court records" means information or data, either in written or electronic form, 17 

maintained by youth court probation offices pertaining to a youth under the jurisdiction of the youth court and 18 

includes reports of preliminary inquiries, youth assessment materials, medical records, school records, and 19 

supervision records of probationers. 20 

(b) The term does not include information provided by the youth court to the department of public 21 

health and human services' management information system. 22 

(26) (a) "Jail" means a facility used for the confinement of adults accused or convicted of criminal 23 

offenses. The term includes a lockup or other facility used primarily for the temporary confinement of adults 24 

after arrest. 25 

(b) The term does not include a collocated juvenile detention facility that complies with 28 CFR, 26 

part 31. 27 

(27) "Judge", when used without further qualification, means the judge of the youth court. 28 



 
****   
68th Legislature 2023   SB 458.1 

 

 - 19 -  Authorized Print Version – SB 458  
 
 

(28) "Juvenile home arrest officer" means a court-appointed officer administering or supervising 1 

juveniles in a program for home arrest, as provided for in Title 46, chapter 18, part 10. 2 

(29) "Law enforcement records" means information or data, either in written or electronic form, 3 

maintained by a law enforcement agency, as defined in 7-32-201, pertaining to a youth covered by this chapter. 4 

(30) (a) "Legal custody" means the legal status created by order of a court of competent jurisdiction 5 

that gives a person the right and duty to: 6 

(i) have physical custody of the youth; 7 

(ii) determine with whom the youth shall live and for what period; 8 

(iii) protect, train, and discipline the youth; and 9 

(iv) provide the youth with food, shelter, education, and ordinary medical care. 10 

(b) An individual granted legal custody of a youth shall personally exercise the individual's rights 11 

and duties as guardian unless otherwise authorized by the court entering the order. 12 

(31) "Necessary parties" includes the youth and the youth's parents, guardian, custodian, or 13 

spouse. 14 

(32) (a) "Out-of-home placement" means placement of a youth in a program, facility, or home, other 15 

than a custodial parent's home, for purposes other than preadjudicatory detention. 16 

(b) The term does not include shelter care or emergency placement of less than 45 days. 17 

(33) (a) "Parent" means the natural or adoptive parent. 18 

(b) The term does not include: 19 

(i) a person whose parental rights have been judicially terminated; or 20 

(ii) the putative father of an illegitimate youth unless the putative father's paternity is established by 21 

an adjudication or by other clear and convincing proof. 22 

(34) "Probable cause hearing" means the hearing provided for in 41-5-332. 23 

(35) "Regional detention facility" means a youth detention facility established and maintained by two 24 

or more counties, as authorized in 41-5-1804. 25 

(36) "Restitution" means payments in cash to the victim or with services to the victim or the general 26 

community when these payments are made pursuant to a consent adjustment, consent decree, or other youth 27 

court order. 28 



 
****   
68th Legislature 2023   SB 458.1 

 

 - 20 -  Authorized Print Version – SB 458  
 
 

(37) "Running away from home" means that a youth has been reported to have run away from 1 

home without the consent of a parent or guardian or a custodian having legal custody of the youth. 2 

(38) "Secure detention facility" means a public or private facility that: 3 

(a) is used for the temporary placement of youth or individuals accused or convicted of criminal 4 

offenses or as a sanction for contempt of court, violation of the terms and conditions of the youth's conditional 5 

release agreement, or violation of a valid court order; and 6 

(b) is designed to physically restrict the movements and activities of youth or other individuals held 7 

in lawful custody of the facility. 8 

(39) "Serious juvenile offender" means a youth who has committed an offense that would be 9 

considered a felony offense if committed by an adult and that is an offense against a person, an offense against 10 

property, or an offense involving dangerous drugs. 11 

(40) "Shelter care" means the temporary substitute care of youth in physically unrestricting facilities. 12 

(41) "Shelter care facility" means a facility used for the shelter care of youth. The term is limited to 13 

the facilities enumerated in 41-5-347. 14 

(42) "Short-term detention center" means a detention facility licensed by the department for the 15 

temporary placement or care of youth, for a period not to exceed 10 days excluding weekends and legal 16 

holidays, pending a probable cause hearing, release, or transfer of the youth to an appropriate detention facility, 17 

youth assessment center, or shelter care facility. 18 

(43) "Substitute care" means full-time care of youth in a residential setting for the purpose of 19 

providing food, shelter, security and safety, guidance, direction, and, if necessary, treatment to youth who are 20 

removed from or are without the care and supervision of their parents or guardians. 21 

(44) "Victim" means: 22 

(a) a person who suffers property, physical, or emotional injury as a result of an offense committed 23 

by a youth that would be a criminal offense if committed by an adult; 24 

(b) an adult relative of the victim, as defined in subsection (44)(a), if the victim is a minor; and 25 

(c) an adult relative of a homicide victim. 26 

(45) "Youth" means an individual who is less than 18 years of age without regard to sex, as defined 27 

in 1-1-201, or emancipation. 28 



 
****   
68th Legislature 2023   SB 458.1 

 

 - 21 -  Authorized Print Version – SB 458  
 
 

(46) "Youth assessment" means a multidisciplinary assessment of a youth as provided in 41-5-1 

1203. 2 

(47) "Youth assessment center" means a staff-secured location that is licensed by the department 3 

of public health and human services to hold a youth for up to 10 days for the purpose of providing an immediate 4 

and comprehensive community-based youth assessment to assist the youth and the youth's family in 5 

addressing the youth's behavior. 6 

(48) "Youth care facility" has the meaning provided in 52-2-602. 7 

(49) "Youth court" means the court established pursuant to this chapter to hear all proceedings in 8 

which a youth is alleged to be a delinquent youth, a youth in need of intervention, or a youth alleged to have 9 

violated the terms and conditions of the youth's conditional release agreement and includes the youth court 10 

judge, juvenile probation officers, and assessment officers. 11 

(50) "Youth detention facility" means a secure detention facility licensed by the department for the 12 

temporary substitute care of youth that is: 13 

(a) (i) operated, administered, and staffed separately and independently of a jail; or 14 

(ii) a collocated secure detention facility that complies with 28 CFR, part 31; and 15 

(b) used exclusively for the lawful detention of alleged or adjudicated delinquent youth or as a 16 

sanction for contempt of court, violation of the terms and conditions of the youth's conditional release 17 

agreement, or violation of a valid court order. 18 

(51) "Youth in need of intervention" means a youth who is adjudicated as a youth and who: 19 

(a) commits an offense prohibited by law that if committed by an adult would not constitute a 20 

criminal offense, including but not limited to a youth who: 21 

(i) violates any Montana municipal or state law regarding alcoholic beverages; or 22 

(ii) continues to exhibit behavior, including running away from home or habitual truancy, beyond 23 

the control of the youth's parents, foster parents, physical custodian, or guardian despite the attempt of the 24 

youth's parents, foster parents, physical custodian, or guardian to exert all reasonable efforts to mediate, 25 

resolve, or control the youth's behavior; or 26 

(b) has committed any of the acts of a delinquent youth but whom the youth court, in its discretion, 27 

chooses to regard as a youth in need of intervention." 28

68th Legislature 2023   SB 458.1 

 

 - 22 -  Authorized Print Version – SB 458  
 
 

 1 

Section 21. Section 42-2-204, MCA, is amended to read: 2 

"42-2-204. Presumed knowledge of pregnancy -- duty to register to be afforded notice -- 3 

putative and presumed fathers. (1) A person who engages in sexual relations with a member of the opposite 4 

sex, as defined in 1-1-201, is presumed to know that a pregnancy could result. 5 

(2) In addition to any other notice to which the putative father is entitled, a putative father is entitled 6 

to notice of termination of parental rights proceedings for the purposes of adoption if the putative father has 7 

complied with the requirements of the putative father registry. 8 

(3) An individual who is not married to the mother but who is presumed to be a father under 40-6-9 

105 and registers in accordance with this part is entitled to receive notice of a termination of parental rights 10 

proceeding." 11 

 12 

Section 22. Section 45-5-625, MCA, is amended to read: 13 

"45-5-625. Sexual abuse of children. (1) A person commits the offense of sexual abuse of children if 14 

the person: 15 

(a) knowingly employs, uses, or permits the employment or use of a child in an exhibition of sexual 16 

conduct, actual or simulated; 17 

(b) knowingly photographs, films, videotapes, develops or duplicates the photographs, films, or 18 

videotapes, or records a child engaging in sexual conduct, actual or simulated; 19 

(c) knowingly, by any means of communication, including electronic communication or in person, 20 

persuades, entices, counsels, coerces, encourages, directs, or procures a child under 16 years of age or a 21 

person the offender believes to be a child under 16 years of age to engage in sexual conduct, actual or 22 

simulated, or to view sexually explicit material or acts for the purpose of inducing or persuading a child to 23 

participate in any sexual activity that is illegal; 24 

(d) knowingly processes, develops, prints, publishes, transports, distributes, sells, exhibits, or 25 

advertises any visual or print medium, including a medium by use of electronic communication in which a child 26 

is engaged in sexual conduct, actual or simulated; 27 

(e) knowingly possesses any visual or print medium, including a medium by use of electronic 28 



 
****   
68th Legislature 2023   SB 458.1 

 

 - 23 -  Authorized Print Version – SB 458  
 
 

communication in which a child is engaged in sexual conduct, actual or simulated; 1 

(f) finances any of the activities described in subsections (1)(a) through (1)(d) and (1)(g), knowing 2 

that the activity is of the nature described in those subsections; 3 

(g) possesses with intent to sell any visual or print medium, including a medium by use of 4 

electronic communication in which a child is engaged in sexual conduct, actual or simulated; 5 

(h) knowingly travels within, from, or to this state with the intention of meeting a child under 16 6 

years of age or a person the offender believes to be a child under 16 years of age in order to engage in sexual 7 

conduct, actual or simulated; or 8 

(i) knowingly coerces, entices, persuades, arranges for, or facilitates a child under 16 years of age 9 

or a person the offender believes to be a child under 16 years of age to travel within, from, or to this state with 10 

the intention of engaging in sexual conduct, actual or simulated. 11 

(2) (a) Except as provided in subsection (2)(b), (2)(c), or (4), a person convicted of the offense of 12 

sexual abuse of children shall be punished by life imprisonment or by imprisonment in the state prison for a 13 

term not to exceed 100 years and may be fined not more than $10,000. 14 

(b) Except as provided in 46-18-219, if the victim is under 16 years of age, a person convicted of 15 

the offense of sexual abuse of children shall be punished by life imprisonment or by imprisonment in the state 16 

prison for a term of not less than 4 years or more than 100 years and may be fined not more than $10,000. 17 

(c) Except as provided in 46-18-219, a person convicted of the offense of sexual abuse of children 18 

for the possession of material, as provided in subsection (1)(e), shall be fined not to exceed $10,000 or be 19 

imprisoned in the state prison for a term not to exceed 10 years, or both. 20 

(3) An offense is not committed under subsections (1)(d) through (1)(g) if the visual or print 21 

medium is processed, developed, printed, published, transported, distributed, sold, possessed, or possessed 22 

with intent to sell, or if the activity is financed, as part of a sexual offender information or treatment course or 23 

program conducted or approved by the department of corrections. 24 

(4) (a) If the victim was 12 years of age or younger and the offender was 18 years of age or older 25 

at the time of the offense, the offender: 26 

(i) shall be punished by imprisonment in a state prison for a term of 100 years. The court may not 27 

suspend execution or defer imposition of the first 25 years of a sentence of imprisonment imposed under this 28 



 
****   
68th Legislature 2023   SB 458.1 

 

 - 24 -  Authorized Print Version – SB 458  
 
 

subsection (4)(a)(i) except as provided in 46-18-222(1) through (5), and during the first 25 years of 1 

imprisonment, the offender is not eligible for parole. The exception provided in 46-18-222(6) does not apply. 2 

(ii) may be fined an amount not to exceed $50,000; and 3 

(iii) shall be ordered to enroll in and successfully complete the educational phase and the cognitive 4 

and behavioral phase of a sexual offender treatment program provided or approved by the department of 5 

corrections. 6 

(b) If the offender is released after the mandatory minimum period of imprisonment, the offender is 7 

subject to supervision by the department of corrections for the remainder of the offender's life and shall 8 

participate in the program for continuous, satellite-based monitoring provided for in 46-23-1010. 9 

(5) As used in this section, the following definitions apply: 10 

(a) "Electronic communication" means a sign, signal, writing, image, sound, data, or intelligence of 11 

any nature transmitted or created in whole or in part by a wire, radio, electromagnetic, photoelectronic, or 12 

photo-optical system. 13 

(b) "Sexual conduct" means: 14 

(i) actual or simulated: 15 

(A) sexual intercourse, whether between persons of the same or opposite sex, as defined in 1-1-16 

201; 17 

(B) penetration of the vagina or rectum by any object, except when done as part of a recognized 18 

medical procedure; 19 

(C) bestiality; 20 

(D) masturbation; 21 

(E) sadomasochistic abuse; 22 

(F) lewd exhibition of the genitals, breasts, pubic or rectal area, or other intimate parts of any 23 

person; or 24 

(G) defecation or urination for the purpose of the sexual stimulation of the viewer; or 25 

(ii) depiction of a child in the nude or in a state of partial undress with the purpose to abuse, 26 

humiliate, harass, or degrade the child or to arouse or gratify the person's own sexual response or desire or the 27 

sexual response or desire of any person. 28 



 
****   
68th Legislature 2023   SB 458.1 

 

 - 25 -  Authorized Print Version – SB 458  
 
 

(c) "Simulated" means any depicting of the genitals or pubic or rectal area that gives the 1 

appearance of sexual conduct or incipient sexual conduct. 2 

(d) "Visual medium" means: 3 

(i) any film, photograph, videotape, negative, slide, or photographic reproduction that contains or 4 

incorporates in any manner any film, photograph, videotape, negative, or slide; or 5 

(ii) any disk, diskette, or other physical media that allows an image to be displayed on a computer 6 

or other video screen and any image transmitted to a computer or other video screen by telephone line, cable, 7 

satellite transmission, or other method." 8 

 9 

Section 23. Section 46-19-301, MCA, is amended to read: 10 

"46-19-301. Western Interstate Corrections Compact -- contents. The Western Interstate 11 

Corrections Compact as contained herein is hereby enacted into law and entered into on behalf of this state 12 

with any and all other states legally joining therein in a form substantially as follows: 13 

WESTERN INTERSTATE CORRECTIONS COMPACT 14 

Article I. Purpose and Policy 15 

The party states, desiring by common action to improve their institutional facilities and provide 16 

programs of sufficiently high quality for the confinement, treatment, and rehabilitation of various types of 17 

offenders, declare that it is the policy of each of the party states to provide such facilities and programs on the 18 

basis of cooperation with one another, thereby serving the best interests of such offenders and of society. The 19 

purpose of this compact is to provide for the development and execution of such programs of cooperation for 20 

the confinement, treatment, and rehabilitation of offenders. 21 

Article II. Definitions 22 

As used in this compact, unless the context clearly requires otherwise: 23 

(1) "state" means a state of the United States or, subject to the limitation contained in Article VII, 24 

Guam; 25 

(2) "sending state" means a state party to this compact in which conviction was had; 26 

(3) "receiving state" means a state party to this compact to which an inmate is sent for confinement 27 

other than a state in which conviction was had; 28 



 
****   
68th Legislature 2023   SB 458.1 

 

 - 26 -  Authorized Print Version – SB 458  
 
 

(4) "inmate" means a male or female, as defined in 1-1-201, offender who is under sentence to or 1 

confined in a prison or other correctional institution; 2 

(5) "institution" means any prison, reformatory, or other correctional facility (including but not 3 

limited to a facility for the mentally ill or mentally defective) in which inmates may lawfully be confined. 4 

Article III. Contracts 5 

(1) Each party state may make one or more contracts with any one or more of the other party 6 

states for the confinement of inmates on behalf of a sending state in institutions situated within receiving states. 7 

Any such contract shall provide for: 8 

(a) its duration; 9 

(b) payments to be made to the receiving state by the sending state for inmate maintenance, 10 

extraordinary medical and dental expenses, and any participation in or receipt by inmates of rehabilitative or 11 

correctional services, facilities, programs, or treatment not reasonably included as part of normal maintenance; 12 

(c) participation in programs of inmate employment, if any; the disposition or crediting of any 13 

payments received by inmates on account thereof; and the crediting of proceeds from or disposal of any 14 

products resulting therefrom; 15 

(d) delivery and retaking of inmates; 16 

(e) such other matters as may be necessary and appropriate to fix the obligations, responsibilities, 17 

and rights of the sending and receiving states. 18 

(2) Prior to the construction or completion of construction of any institution or addition thereto by a 19 

party state, any other party state or states may contract therewith for the enlargement of the planned capacity 20 

of the institution or addition thereto, or for the inclusion therein of particular equipment or structures, and for the 21 

reservation of a specific percent of the capacity of the institution to be kept available for use by inmates of the 22 

sending state or states so contracting. Any sending state so contracting may, to the extent that moneys are 23 

legally available therefor, pay to the receiving state a reasonable sum as consideration for such enlargement of 24 

capacity or provision of equipment or structures and reservation of capacity. Such payment may be in a lump 25 

sum or in installments as provided in the contract. 26 

(3) The terms and provisions of this compact shall be a part of any contract entered into by the 27 

authority of or pursuant thereto, and nothing in any such contract shall be inconsistent therewith. 28 



 
****   
68th Legislature 2023   SB 458.1 

 

 - 27 -  Authorized Print Version – SB 458  
 
 

Article IV. Procedures and Rights 1 

(1) Whenever the duly constituted judicial or administrative authorities in a state party to this 2 

compact, and which has entered into a contract pursuant to Article III, shall decide that confinement in or 3 

transfer of an inmate to an institution within the territory of another party state is necessary in order to provide 4 

adequate quarters and care or desirable in order to provide an appropriate program of rehabilitation or 5 

treatment, said officials may direct that the confinement be within an institution within the territory of said other 6 

party state, the receiving state to act in that regard solely as agent for the sending state. 7 

(2) The appropriate officials of any state party to this compact shall have access at all reasonable 8 

times to any institution in which it has a contractual right to confine inmates for the purpose of inspecting the 9 

facilities thereof and visiting such of its inmates as may be confined in the institution. 10 

(3) Inmates confined in an institution pursuant to the terms of this compact shall at all times be 11 

subject to the jurisdiction of the sending state and may at any time be removed therefrom for transfer to a 12 

prison or other institution within the sending state, for transfer to another institution in which the sending state 13 

may have a contractual or other right to confine inmates, for release on probation or parole, for discharge, or for 14 

any other purpose permitted by the laws of the sending state; provided that the sending state shall continue to 15 

be obligated to such payments as may be required pursuant to the terms of any contract entered into under the 16 

terms of Article III. 17 

(4) Each receiving state shall provide regular reports to each sending state on the inmates of that 18 

sending state in institutions pursuant to this compact including a conduct record of each inmate and certify said 19 

record to the official designated by the sending state in order that each inmate may have the benefit of the 20 

inmate's record in determining and altering the disposition of said inmate in accordance with the law which may 21 

obtain in the sending state and in order that the same may be a source of information for the sending state. 22 

(5) All inmates who may be confined in an institution pursuant to the provisions of this compact 23 

shall be treated in a reasonable and humane manner and shall be cared for and treated equally with such 24 

similar inmates of the receiving state as may be confined in the same institution. The fact of confinement in a 25 

receiving state shall not deprive any inmate so confined of any legal rights which said inmate would have had if 26 

confined in an appropriate institution of the sending state. 27 

(6) Any hearing or hearings to which an inmate confined pursuant to this compact may be entitled 28 



 
****   
68th Legislature 2023   SB 458.1 

 

 - 28 -  Authorized Print Version – SB 458  
 
 

by the laws of the sending state may be had before the appropriate authorities of the sending state or of the 1 

receiving state if authorized by the sending state. The receiving state shall provide adequate facilities for such 2 

hearings as may be conducted by the appropriate officials of a sending state. In the event such hearing or 3 

hearings are had before officials of the receiving state, the governing law shall be that of the sending state and 4 

a record of the hearing or hearings as prescribed by the sending state shall be made. Said record together with 5 

any recommendations of the hearing officials shall be transmitted forthwith to the official or officials before 6 

whom the hearing would have been had if it had taken place in the sending state. In any and all proceedings 7 

had pursuant to the provisions of this subdivision, the officials of the receiving state shall act solely as agents of 8 

the sending state and no final determination shall be made in any matter except by the appropriate officials of 9 

the sending state. Costs of records made pursuant to this subsection shall be borne by the sending state. 10 

(7) Any inmate confined pursuant to this compact shall be released within the territory of the 11 

sending state unless the inmate and the sending and receiving states shall agree upon release in some other 12 

place. The sending state shall bear the cost of such return to its territory. 13 

(8) Any inmate confined pursuant to the terms of this compact shall have any and all rights to 14 

participate in and derive any benefits, incur or be relieved of any obligations, or have such obligations modified 15 

or the inmate's status changed on account of any action or proceeding in which the inmate could have 16 

participated if confined in any appropriate institution of the sending state located within such state. 17 

(9) The parent, guardian, trustee, or other person or persons entitled under the laws of the sending 18 

state to act for, advise, or otherwise function with respect to any inmate shall not be deprived of or restricted in 19 

the person's exercise of any power in respect of any inmate confined pursuant to the terms of this compact. 20 

Article V. Acts Not Reviewable in Receiving State -- Extradition 21 

(1) Any decision of the sending state in respect of any matter over which it retains jurisdiction 22 

pursuant to this compact shall be conclusive upon and not reviewable within the receiving state, but if at the 23 

time the sending state seeks to remove an inmate from an institution in the receiving state there is pending 24 

against the inmate within such state any criminal charge or if the inmate is suspected of having committed 25 

within such state a criminal offense, the inmate shall not be returned without the consent of the receiving state 26 

until discharged from prosecution or other form of proceeding, imprisonment, or detention for such offense. The 27 

duly accredited officers of the sending state shall be permitted to transport inmates pursuant to this compact 28 



 
****   
68th Legislature 2023   SB 458.1 

 

 - 29 -  Authorized Print Version – SB 458  
 
 

through any and all states party to this compact without interference. 1 

(2) An inmate who escapes from an institution in which the inmate is confined pursuant to this 2 

compact shall be deemed a fugitive from the sending state and from the state in which the institution is situated. 3 

In the case of an escape to a jurisdiction other than the sending or receiving state, the responsibility for 4 

institution of extradition proceedings shall be that of the sending state, but nothing contained herein shall be 5 

construed to prevent or affect the activities of officers and agencies of any jurisdiction directed toward the 6 

apprehension and return of an escapee. 7 

Article VI. Federal Aid 8 

Any state party to this compact may accept federal aid for use in connection with any institution or 9 

program, the use of which is or may be affected by this compact or any contract pursuant hereto, and any 10 

inmate in a receiving state pursuant to this compact may participate in any such federally aided program or 11 

activity for which the sending and receiving states have made contractual provision, provided that, if such 12 

program or activity is not part of the customary correctional regimen, the express consent of the appropriate 13 

official of the sending state shall be required therefor. 14 

Article VII. Entry into Force 15 

This compact shall enter into force and become effective and binding upon the states so acting when it 16 

has been enacted into law by any two contiguous states from among the states of Alaska, Arizona, California, 17 

Colorado, Hawaii, Idaho, Montana, Nebraska, Nevada, New Mexico, Oregon, Utah, Washington, and Wyoming. 18 

For the purposes of this article, Alaska and Hawaii shall be deemed contiguous to each other; to any and all of 19 

the states of California, Oregon, and Washington; and to Guam. Thereafter, this compact shall enter into force 20 

and become effective and binding as to any other of said states or any other state contiguous to at least one 21 

party state upon similar action by such state. Guam may become party to this compact by taking action similar 22 

to that provided for joinder by any other eligible party state and upon the consent of congress to such joinder. 23 

For the purposes of this article, Guam shall be deemed contiguous to Alaska, Hawaii, California, Oregon, and 24 

Washington. 25 

Article VIII. Withdrawal and Termination 26 

This compact shall continue in force and remain binding upon a party state until it shall have enacted a 27 

statute repealing the same and providing for the sending of formal written notice of withdrawal from the 28 



 
****   
68th Legislature 2023   SB 458.1 

 

 - 30 -  Authorized Print Version – SB 458  
 
 

compact to the appropriate officials of all other party states. An actual withdrawal shall not take effect until 2 1 

years after the notices provided in said statute have been sent. Such withdrawal shall not relieve the 2 

withdrawing state from its obligations assumed hereunder prior to the effective date of withdrawal. Before the 3 

effective date of withdrawal, a withdrawing state shall remove to its territory, at its own expense, such inmates 4 

as it may have confined pursuant to the provisions of this compact. 5 

Article IX. Other Arrangements Unaffected 6 

Nothing contained in this compact shall be construed to abrogate or impair any agreement or other 7 

arrangement which a party state may have with a nonparty state for the confinement, rehabilitation, or 8 

treatment of inmates or to repeal any other laws of a party state authorizing the making of cooperative 9 

institutional arrangements. 10 

Article X. Construction and Severability 11 

The provisions of this compact shall be liberally construed and shall be severable. If any phrase, 12 

clause, sentence, or provision of this compact is declared to be contrary to the constitution of any participating 13 

state or of the United States or the applicability thereof to any government, agency, person, or circumstance is 14 

held invalid, the validity of the remainder of this compact and the applicability thereof to any government, 15 

agency, person, or circumstance shall not be affected thereby. If this compact shall be held contrary to the 16 

constitution of any state participating therein, the compact shall remain in full force and effect as to the 17 

remaining states and in full force and effect as to the state affected as to all severable matters." 18 

 19 

Section 24. Section 46-19-401, MCA, is amended to read: 20 

"46-19-401. Compact adopted -- text. The Interstate Corrections Compact is entered into by this 21 

state with any and all other states legally joining therein in the form substantially as follows: 22 

INTERSTATE CORRECTIONS COMPACT 23 

Article I. Purpose and Policy 24 

The party states, desiring by common action to fully utilize and improve their institutional facilities and 25 

provide adequate programs for the confinement, treatment and rehabilitation of various types of offenders, 26 

declare that it is the policy of each of the party states to provide such facilities and programs on a basis of 27 

cooperation with one another, thereby serving the best interests of such offenders and of society and effecting 28 



 
****   
68th Legislature 2023   SB 458.1 

 

 - 31 -  Authorized Print Version – SB 458  
 
 

economies in capital expenditures and operational costs. The purpose of this compact is to provide for the 1 

mutual development and execution of such programs of cooperation for the confinement, treatment and 2 

rehabilitation of offenders with the most economical use of human and material resources. 3 

Article II. Definitions 4 

As used in this compact, unless the context requires otherwise: 5 

(a) "State" means a state of the United States; the United States of America; a territory or 6 

possession of the United States; the District of Columbia; the Commonwealth of Puerto Rico. 7 

(b) "Sending state" means a state party to this compact in which conviction or court commitment 8 

was had. 9 

(c) "Receiving state" means a state party to this compact to which an inmate is sent for 10 

confinement other than a state in which conviction or court commitment was had. 11 

(d) "Inmate" means a male or female, as defined in 1-1-201, offender who is committed under 12 

sentence to or confined in a penal or correctional institution. 13 

(e) "Institution" means any penal or correctional facility, including but not limited to a facility for the 14 

mentally ill or mentally defective, in which inmates may lawfully be confined. 15 

Article III. Contracts 16 

(a) Each party state may make one or more contracts with any one or more of the other party 17 

states for the confinement of inmates on behalf of a sending state in institutions situated within receiving states. 18 

Any such contract shall provide for: 19 

1. Its duration. 20 

2. Payments to be made to the receiving state by the sending state for inmate maintenance, 21 

extraordinary medical and dental expenses, and any participation in or receipt by inmates of rehabilitative or 22 

correctional services, facilities, programs or treatment not reasonably included as part of normal maintenance. 23 

3. Participation in programs of inmate employment, if any; the disposition or crediting of any 24 

payments received by inmates on account thereof; and the crediting of proceeds from or disposal of any 25 

products resulting therefrom. 26 

4. Delivery and retaking of inmates. 27 

5. Such other matters as may be necessary and appropriate to fix the obligations, responsibilities 28 



 
****   
68th Legislature 2023   SB 458.1 

 

 - 32 -  Authorized Print Version – SB 458  
 
 

and rights of the sending and receiving states. 1 

(b) The terms and provisions of this compact shall be a part of any contract entered into by the 2 

authority of or pursuant thereto, and nothing in any such contract shall be inconsistent therewith. 3 

Article IV. Procedures and Rights 4 

(a) Whenever the duly constituted authorities in a state party to this compact, and which has 5 

entered into a contract pursuant to Article III, shall decide that confinement in, or transfer of an inmate to, an 6 

institution within the territory of another party state is necessary or desirable in order to provide adequate 7 

quarters and care or an appropriate program of rehabilitation or treatment, said officials may direct that the 8 

confinement be within an institution within the territory of said other party state, the receiving state to act in that 9 

regard solely as agent for the sending state. 10 

(b) The appropriate officials of any state party to this compact shall have access, at all reasonable 11 

times, to any institution in which it has a contractual right to confine inmates for the purpose of inspecting the 12 

facilities thereof and visiting such of its inmates as may be confined in the institution. 13 

(c) Inmates confined in an institution pursuant to the terms of this compact shall at all times be 14 

subject to the jurisdiction of the sending state and may at any time be removed therefrom for transfer to a 15 

prison or other institution within the sending state. For transfer to another institution in which the sending state 16 

may have a contractual or other right to confine inmates, for release on probation or parole, for discharge, or for 17 

any other purpose permitted by the laws of the sending state; provided that the sending state shall continue to 18 

be obligated to such payments as may be required pursuant to the terms of any contract entered into under the 19 

terms of Article III. 20 

(d) Each receiving state shall provide regular reports to each sending state on the inmates of that 21 

sending state in institutions pursuant to this compact including a conduct record of each inmate and certify said 22 

record to the official designated by the sending state, in order that each inmate may have official review of the 23 

inmate's record in determining and altering the disposition of said inmate in accordance with the law which may 24 

obtain in the sending state and in order that the same may be a source of information for the sending state. 25 

(e) All inmates who may be confined in an institution pursuant to the provisions of this compact 26 

shall be treated in a reasonable and humane manner and shall be treated equally with such similar inmates of 27 

the receiving state as may be confined in the same institution. The fact of confinement in a receiving state shall 28 



 
****   
68th Legislature 2023   SB 458.1 

 

 - 33 -  Authorized Print Version – SB 458  
 
 

not deprive any inmate so confined of any legal rights which said inmate would have had if confined in an 1 

appropriate institution of the sending state. 2 

(f) Any hearing or hearings to which an inmate confined pursuant to this compact may be entitled 3 

by the laws of the sending state may be had before the appropriate authorities of the sending state, or of the 4 

receiving state if authorized by the sending state. The receiving state shall provide adequate facilities for such 5 

hearings as may be conducted by the appropriate officials of a sending state. In the event such hearing or 6 

hearings are had before officials of the receiving state, the governing law shall be that of the sending state and 7 

a record of the hearing or hearings as prescribed by the sending state shall be made. Said record together with 8 

any recommendations of the hearing officials shall be transmitted forthwith to the official or officials before 9 

whom the hearing would have been had if it had taken place in the sending state. In any and all proceedings 10 

had pursuant to the provisions of this subsection, the officials of the receiving state shall act solely as agents of 11 

the sending state and no final determination shall be made in any matter except by the appropriate officials of 12 

the sending state. 13 

(g) Any inmate confined pursuant to this compact shall be released within the territory of the 14 

sending state unless the inmate, and the sending and receiving states, shall agree upon release in some other 15 

place. The sending state shall bear the cost of such return to its territory. 16 

(h) Any inmate confined pursuant to the terms of this compact shall have any and all rights to 17 

participate in and derive any benefits or incur or be relieved of any obligations or have such obligations 18 

modified or the inmate's status changed on account of any action or proceeding in which the inmate could have 19 

participated if confined in any appropriate institution of the sending state located within such state. 20 

(i) The parent, guardian, trustee, or other person or persons entitled under the laws of the sending 21 

state to act for, advise, or otherwise function with respect to any inmate shall not be deprived of or restricted in 22 

the inmate's exercise of any power in respect of any inmate confined pursuant to the terms of this compact. 23 

Article V. Acts Not Reviewable in Receiving State -- Extradition 24 

(a) Any decision of the sending state in respect of any matter over which it retains jurisdiction 25 

pursuant to this compact shall be conclusive upon and not reviewable within the receiving state, but if at the 26 

time the sending state seeks to remove an inmate from an institution in the receiving state there is pending 27 

against the inmate within such state any criminal charge or if the inmate is formally accused of having 28 



 
****   
68th Legislature 2023   SB 458.1 

 

 - 34 -  Authorized Print Version – SB 458  
 
 

committed within such state a criminal offense, the inmate shall not be returned without the consent of the 1 

receiving state until discharged from prosecution or other form of proceeding, imprisonment or detention for 2 

such offense. The duly accredited officers of the sending state shall be permitted to transport inmates pursuant 3 

to this compact through any and all states party to this compact without interference. 4 

(b) An inmate who escapes from an institution in which the inmate is confined pursuant to this 5 

compact shall be deemed a fugitive from the sending state and from the state in which the institution is situated. 6 

In the case of an escape to a jurisdiction other than the sending or receiving state, the responsibility for 7 

institution of extradition or rendition proceedings shall be that of the sending state, but nothing contained herein 8 

shall be construed to prevent or affect the activities of officers and agencies of any jurisdiction directed toward 9 

the apprehension and return of an escapee. 10 

Article VI. Federal Aid 11 

Any state party to this compact may accept federal aid for use in connection with any institution or 12 

program, the use of which is or may be affected by this compact or any contract pursuant hereto and any 13 

inmate in a receiving state pursuant to this compact may participate in any such federally aided program or 14 

activity for which the sending and receiving states have made contractual provision, provided that if such 15 

program or activity is not part of the customary correctional regimen, the express consent of the appropriate 16 

official of the sending state shall be required therefor. 17 

Article VII. Entry Into Force 18 

This compact shall enter into force and become effective and binding upon the states so acting when it 19 

has been enacted into law by any two states. Thereafter, this compact shall enter into force and become 20 

effective and binding as to any other of said states upon similar action by such state. 21 

Article VIII. Withdrawal and Termination 22 

This compact shall continue in force and remain binding upon a party state until it shall have enacted a 23 

statute repealing the same and providing for the sending of formal written notice of withdrawal from the 24 

compact to the appropriate officials of all other party states. An actual withdrawal shall not take effect until one 25 

year after the notices provided in said statute have been sent. Such withdrawal shall not relieve the withdrawing 26 

state from its obligations assumed hereunder prior to the effective date of withdrawal. Before the effective date 27 

of withdrawal, a withdrawing state shall remove to its territory, at its own expense, such inmates as it may have 28 



 
****   
68th Legislature 2023   SB 458.1 

 

 - 35 -  Authorized Print Version – SB 458  
 
 

confined pursuant to the provisions of this compact. 1 

Article IX. Other Arrangements Unaffected 2 

Nothing contained in this compact shall be construed to abrogate or impair any agreement or other 3 

arrangement which a party state may have with a nonparty state for the confinement, rehabilitation or treatment 4 

of inmates nor to repeal any other laws of a party state authorizing the making of cooperative institutional 5 

arrangements. 6 

Article X. Construction and Severability 7 

The provisions of this compact shall be liberally construed and shall be severable. If any phrase, 8 

clause, sentence or provision of this compact is declared to be contrary to the constitution of any participating 9 

state or of the United States or the applicability thereof to any government, agency, person or circumstance is 10 

held invalid, the validity of the remainder of this compact and the applicability thereof to any government, 11 

agency, person or circumstance shall not be affected thereby. If this compact shall be held contrary to the 12 

constitution of any state participating therein, the compact shall remain in full force and effect as to the 13 

remaining states and in full force and effect as to the state affected as to all severable matters." 14

Section 25. Section 46-32-105, MCA, is amended to read: 16 

"46-32-105. (Temporary) Expungement. (1) Upon entry of a certificate of innocence, the court shall 17 

order the associated convictions and arrest records expunged and purged from all applicable systems, 18 

including both electronic and hard copy systems. The court shall enter the expungement order regardless of 19 

whether the claimant has prior criminal convictions in other cases that are not the subject of the claim for 20 

compensation. 21 

(2) The order of expungement must state: 22 

(a) the claimant's current full name; 23 

(b) the claimant's full name at the time of arrest and conviction, if different from the claimant's 24 

current name; 25 

(c) the claimant's sex, as defined in 1-1-201, race, and date of birth; 26 

(d) the crime for which the claimant was arrested and convicted; 27 

(e) the date of the claimant's arrest and the date of the claimant's conviction; and 28 



 
****   
68th Legislature 2023   SB 458.1 

 

 - 36 -  Authorized Print Version – SB 458  
 
 

(f) the identity of the arresting law enforcement authority and the identity of the district court that 1 

rendered the conviction. 2 

(3) The order of expungement also must direct the department of justice to purge the conviction 3 

and arrest information from the central repository of the criminal justice information network and all applicable 4 

databases. The clerk of the court shall send a certified copy of the order to the department of justice for 5 

immediate action, and the department shall carry out the order and notify the federal bureau of investigation, 6 

the department of corrections, and any other criminal justice agency that may have a record of the conviction 7 

and arrest. The department of justice shall provide confirmation of the action to the court. 8 

(4) If a certificate of innocence and an order of expungement are entered, the claimant must be 9 

treated as not having been arrested or convicted of the crime or crimes to which the certificate of innocence 10 

applies. 11 

(5) (a) Upon entry of a certificate of innocence: 12 

(i) the court shall order the expungement and destruction of any associated biological samples 13 

from the claimant. The order must state the information required to be expunged and destroyed. 14 

(ii) the court shall seal all district court records regarding the conviction. The district court records 15 

are only available upon a good cause finding by the court. 16 

(iii) the clerk of the court shall send a certified copy of the order to the department of justice, which 17 

must carry out the order and provide confirmation of the action to the court. 18 

(b) The department is not required to expunge and destroy any samples record associated with 19 

the claimant related to an offense other than the offense or offenses for which the court has entered a 20 

certificate of innocence. 21 

(6) The decision to grant or deny a certificate of innocence does not have a res judicata effect on 22 

any other criminal proceedings involving the claimant. (Terminates June 30, 2023--sec. 15, Ch. 574, L. 2021.)" 23 

 24 

Section 26. Section 49-1-102, MCA, is amended to read: 25 

"49-1-102. Freedom from discrimination. (1) The right to be free from discrimination because of 26 

race, creed, religion, color, sex, as defined in 1-1-201, physical or mental disability, age, or national origin is 27 

recognized as and declared to be a civil right. This right must include but not be limited to: 28 



 
****   
68th Legislature 2023   SB 458.1 

 

 - 37 -  Authorized Print Version – SB 458  
 
 

(a) the right to obtain and hold employment without discrimination; and 1 

(b) the right to the full enjoyment of any of the accommodation facilities or privileges of any place 2 

of public resort, accommodation, assemblage, or amusement. 3 

(2) This section does not prevent the nonarbitrary consideration in adoption proceedings of 4 

relevant information concerning the factors listed in subsection (1). Consideration of religious factors by a 5 

licensed child-placing agency that is affiliated with a particular religious faith is not arbitrary consideration of 6 

religion within the meaning of this section." 7 

 8 

Section 27. Section 49-2-101, MCA, is amended to read: 9 

"49-2-101. Definitions. As used in this chapter, unless the context requires otherwise, the following 10 

definitions apply: 11 

(1) "Age" means number of years since birth. It does not mean level of maturity or ability to handle 12 

responsibility. These latter criteria may represent legitimate considerations as reasonable grounds for 13 

discrimination without reference to age. 14 

(2) "Aggrieved party" means a person who can demonstrate a specific personal and legal interest, 15 

as distinguished from a general interest, and who has been or is likely to be specially and injuriously affected by 16 

a violation of this chapter. 17 

(3) "Commission" means the commission for human rights provided for in 2-15-1706. 18 

(4) "Commissioner" means the commissioner of labor and industry provided for in 2-15-1701. 19 

(5) "Credit" means the right granted by a creditor to a person to defer payment of a debt, to incur 20 

debt and defer its payment, or to purchase property or services and defer payment. It includes without limitation 21 

the right to incur and defer debt that is secured by residential real property. 22 

(6) "Credit transaction" means any invitation to apply for credit, application for credit, extension of 23 

credit, or credit sale. 24 

(7) "Creditor" means a person who, regularly or as a part of the person's business, arranges for 25 

the extension of credit for which the payment of a financial charge or interest is required, whether in connection 26 

with loans, sale of property or services, or otherwise. 27 

(8) "Department" means the department of labor and industry provided for in 2-15-1701. 28 



 
****   
68th Legislature 2023   SB 458.1 

 

 - 38 -  Authorized Print Version – SB 458  
 
 

(9) "Educational institution" means a public or private institution and includes an academy; college; 1 

elementary or secondary school; extension course; kindergarten; nursery; school system; university; business, 2 

nursing, professional, secretarial, technical, or vocational school; or agent of an educational institution. 3 

(10) (a) "Employee" means an individual employed by an employer. 4 

(b) The term does not include an individual providing services for an employer if the individual has 5 

an independent contractor exemption certificate issued under 39-71-417 and is providing services under the 6 

terms of that certificate. 7 

(11) "Employer" means an employer of one or more persons or an agent of the employer but does 8 

not include a fraternal, charitable, or religious association or corporation if the association or corporation is not 9 

organized either for private profit or to provide accommodations or services that are available on a 10 

nonmembership basis. 11 

(12) "Employment agency" means a person undertaking to procure employees or opportunities to 12 

work. 13 

(13) "Financial institution" means a commercial bank, trust company, savings bank, finance 14 

company, savings and loan association, credit union, investment company, or insurance company. 15 

(14) "Housing accommodation" means a building or portion of a building, whether constructed or to 16 

be constructed, that is or will be used as the sleeping quarters of its occupants. 17 

(15) "Labor organization" means an organization or an agent of an organization organized for the 18 

purpose, in whole or in part, of collective bargaining, of dealing with employers concerning grievances or terms 19 

or conditions of employment, or of other mutual aid and protection of employees. 20 

(16) "National origin" means ancestry. 21 

(17) (a) "Organization" means a corporation, association, or any other legal or commercial entity 22 

that engages in advocacy of, enforcement of, or compliance with legal interests affected by this chapter. 23 

(b) The term does not include a labor organization. 24 

(18) "Person" means one or more individuals, labor unions, partnerships, associations, 25 

corporations, legal representatives, mutual companies, joint-stock companies, trusts, unincorporated 26 

employees' associations, employers, employment agencies, organizations, or labor organizations. 27 

(19) (a) "Physical or mental disability" means: 28 



 
****   
68th Legislature 2023   SB 458.1 

 

 - 39 -  Authorized Print Version – SB 458  
 
 

(i) a physical or mental impairment that substantially limits one or more of a person's major life 1 

activities; 2 

(ii) a record of such an impairment; or 3 

(iii) a condition regarded as such an impairment. 4 

(b) Discrimination based on, because of, on the basis of, or on the grounds of physical or mental 5 

disability includes the failure to make reasonable accommodations that are required by an otherwise qualified 6 

person who has a physical or mental disability. An accommodation that would require an undue hardship or that 7 

would endanger the health or safety of any person is not a reasonable accommodation. 8 

(20) (a) "Public accommodation" means a place that caters or offers its services, goods, or facilities 9 

to the general public subject only to the conditions and limitations established by law and applicable to all 10 

persons. It includes without limitation a public inn, restaurant, eating house, hotel, roadhouse, place where food 11 

or alcoholic beverages or malt liquors are sold for consumption, motel, soda fountain, soft drink parlor, tavern, 12 

nightclub, trailer park, resort, campground, barbering, barbering nonchemical, cosmetology, electrology, 13 

esthetics, or manicuring salon or shop, bathroom, resthouse, theater, swimming pool, skating rink, golf course, 14 

cafe, ice cream parlor, transportation company, or hospital and all other public amusement and business 15 

establishments. 16 

(b) Public accommodation does not include an institution, club, or place of accommodation that 17 

proves that it is by its nature distinctly private. An institution, club, or place of accommodation may not be 18 

considered by its nature distinctly private if it has more than 100 members, provides regular meal service, and 19 

regularly receives payment for dues, fees, use of space, facilities, services, meals, or beverages, directly or 20 

indirectly, from or on behalf of nonmembers, for the furtherance of trade or business. For the purposes of this 21 

subsection (20), any lodge of a recognized national fraternal organization is considered by its nature distinctly 22 

private." 23 

(21) "Sex" has the meaning provided in 1-1-201. 24

Section 29. Section 50-5-105, MCA, is amended to read: 22 

"50-5-105. Discrimination prohibited. (1) All phases of the operation of a health care facility must be 23 

without discrimination against anyone on the basis of race, creed, religion, color, national origin, sex, as defined 24 

in 1-1-201, age, marital status, physical or mental disability, or political ideas. 25 

(2) (a) A health care facility may not refuse to admit a person to the facility solely because the 26 

person has an HIV-related condition. 27 

(b) For the purposes of this subsection (2), the following definitions apply: 28 



 
****   
68th Legislature 2023   SB 458.1 

 

 - 41 -  Authorized Print Version – SB 458  
 
 

(i) "HIV" means the human immunodeficiency virus identified as the causative agent of acquired 1 

immunodeficiency syndrome (AIDS) and includes all HIV and HIV-related viruses that damage the cellular 2 

branch of the human immune or neurological system and leave the infected person immunodeficient or 3 

neurologically impaired. 4 

(ii) "HIV-related condition" means any medical condition resulting from an HIV infection, including 5 

but not limited to seropositivity for HIV. 6 

(3) A person who operates a facility may not discriminate among the patients of licensed 7 

physicians. The free and confidential professional relationship between a licensed physician and patient must 8 

continue and remain unaffected. 9 

(4) Except for a hospital that employs its medical staff, a hospital considering an application for 10 

staff membership or granting privileges within the scope of the applicant's license may not deny the application 11 

or privileges because the applicant is licensed under Title 37, chapter 6." 12

(c) appointed by a court to manage the personal or financial affairs of an individual. 21

concluded that death occurred. 23 

(4) "Department" means the department of public health and human services provided for in 2-15-24 

2201. 25 

(5) "Dissolution of marriage" means a marriage terminated pursuant to Title 40, chapter 4, part 1. 26 

(6) "Fetal death" means death of the fetus prior to the complete expulsion or extraction from its 27 

mother as a product of conception, notwithstanding the duration of pregnancy. The death is indicated by the 28 



 
****   
68th Legislature 2023   SB 458.1 

 

 - 43 -  Authorized Print Version – SB 458  
 
 

fact that after expulsion or extraction, the fetus does not breathe or show any other evidence of life, such as 1 

beating of the heart, pulsation of the umbilical cord, or definite movement of voluntary muscles. Heartbeats are 2 

distinguished from transient cardiac contractions. Respirations are distinguished from fleeting respiratory efforts 3 

or gasps. 4 

(7) "Final disposition" means the burial, interment, cremation, removal from the state, or other 5 

authorized disposition of a dead body or fetus. 6 

(8) "Invalid marriage" means a marriage decreed by a district court to be invalid for the reasons 7 

contained in 40-1-402. 8 

(9) "Live birth" means the complete expulsion or extraction from the mother as a product of 9 

conception, notwithstanding the duration of pregnancy. The birth is indicated by the fact that after expulsion or 10 

extraction, the child breathes or shows any other evidence of life, such as beating of the heart, pulsation of the 11 

umbilical cord, or definite movement of voluntary muscles. Heartbeats are distinguished from transient cardiac 12

of the body or fetus and who is a funeral director, an employee acting for a funeral director, or a person who 18 

first assumes custody of a dead body or fetus. 19 

(12) "Physician" means a person legally authorized to practice medicine in this state. 20
