Section 33. Section 50-19-103, MCA, is amended to read: 8 

"50-19-103. Prenatal blood sample required for serological test. (1) Every female, as defined in 1-9 

1-201, regardless of age or marital status, seeking prenatal care from a health care provider is required to 10 

submit a blood specimen for the purpose of a standard serological test. In submitting the specimen to the 11 

laboratory, the health care provider shall designate it as a prenatal test. 12 

(2) A health care provider who attends a pregnant woman shall at the first professional visit take 13 

the blood sample and submit it to a laboratory. 14 

(3) A person permitted to attend a pregnant woman, but not permitted to take blood samples, must 15 

have the sample taken by a person permitted to take blood samples and submit it to a laboratory. 16 

(4) A health care provider who violates this part is guilty of a misdemeanor. However, a health care 17 

provider who requests a sample of blood in accordance with this provision and whose request is refused is not 18 

guilty of a violation of this section." 19 

 20 

Section 34. Section 50-60-214, MCA, is amended to read: 21 

"50-60-214. Alteration of primary function area. (1) An alteration that affects or could affect the use 22 

of or access to a primary function area in a public building must be made to ensure, to the extent possible, that 23 

the path of travel to the altered primary function area and the restrooms, telephones, and drinking fountains 24 

serving the altered primary function area are readily accessible and usable by persons with disabilities. 25 

(2) (a) A person or entity is not required to make alterations to provide an accessible path of travel 26 

to an altered primary function area if in terms of cost and scope the alterations to the path of travel are 27 

disproportionate to the cost of the alterations to the primary function area. Alterations to a path of travel to an 28 



 
****   
68th Legislature 2023   SB 458.1 

 

 - 45 -  Authorized Print Version – SB 458  
 
 

altered primary function area must be considered disproportionate if the cost exceeds 20% of the cost of the 1 

alterations to the primary function area. This subsection does not prohibit an expenditure to alter a path of travel 2 

that exceeds 20% of the cost of the alterations to a primary function area. 3 

(b) If the cost of altering a path of travel to an altered primary function area is disproportionate as 4 

provided in subsection (2)(a), the path of travel must be made accessible to the extent possible without 5 

incurring disproportionate costs. The alterations to the path of travel must be made by providing, in the following 6 

order or priority: 7 

(i) an accessible entrance and accessible exterior route to the accessible entrance from 8 

accessible parking and passenger loading zones or from a public sidewalk if the public sidewalk is immediately 9 

adjacent to the public building site; 10 

(ii) an accessible path of travel to the altered primary function area; 11 

(iii) accessible restrooms for each sex, as defined in 1-1-201, or a single unisex restroom when 12 

allowed by the applicable building code; and 13 

(iv) accessible elements, including but not limited to storage spaces and alarms. 14 

(3) A person or entity subject to the provisions of this section is also subject to the provisions of 50-15 

60-213(5)(a) and (5)(b)." 16 

 17 

Section 35. Section 53-20-142, MCA, is amended to read: 18 

"53-20-142. Rights while in residential facility. Persons admitted to a residential facility for a period 19 

of habilitation have the following rights: 20 

(1) Residents have a right to dignity, privacy, and humane care. 21 

(2) Residents are entitled to send and receive sealed mail. Moreover, it is the duty of the facility to 22 

foster the exercise of this right by furnishing the necessary materials and assistance. 23 

(3) Residents must have the same rights and access to private telephone communication as 24 

patients at any public hospital except to the extent that the individual treatment planning team or the qualified 25 

intellectual disability professional responsible for formulation of a particular resident's habilitation plan writes an 26 

order imposing special restrictions and explains the reasons for the restrictions. The written order must be 27 

renewed monthly if any restrictions are to be continued. 28 



 
****   
68th Legislature 2023   SB 458.1 

 

 - 46 -  Authorized Print Version – SB 458  
 
 

(4) Residents have an unrestricted right to visitation except to the extent that the individual 1 

treatment planning team or the qualified intellectual disability professional responsible for formulation of a 2 

particular resident's habilitation plan writes an order imposing special restrictions and explains the reasons for 3 

the restrictions. The written order must be renewed monthly if restrictions are to be continued. 4 

(5) Residents have a right to receive suitable educational and habilitation services regardless of 5 

chronological age, degree of intellectual disability, or accompanying disabilities. 6 

(6) Each resident must have an adequate allowance of neat, clean, suitably fitting, and seasonable 7 

clothing. Except when a particular kind of clothing is required because of a particular condition, residents must 8 

have the opportunity to select from various types of neat, clean, and seasonable clothing. The clothing must be 9 

considered the resident's throughout the resident's stay in the facility. Clothing, both in amount and type, must 10 

make it possible for residents to go out of doors in inclement weather, to go for trips or visits appropriately 11 

dressed, and to make a normal appearance in the community. The facility shall make provision for the 12 

adequate and regular laundering of the residents' clothing. 13 

(7) Each resident has the right to keep and use the resident's own personal possessions except 14 

insofar as the clothes or personal possessions may be determined by the individual treatment planning team or 15 

the qualified intellectual disability professional to be dangerous either to the resident or to others. 16 

(8) Each resident has a right to a humane physical environment within the residential facility. The 17 

facility must be designed to make a positive contribution to the efficient attainment of the habilitation goals of 18 

the resident. To accomplish this purpose: 19 

(a) regular housekeeping and maintenance procedures that will ensure that the facility is 20 

maintained in a safe, clean, and attractive condition must be developed and implemented; 21 

(b) pursuant to an established routine maintenance and repair program, the physical plant must be 22 

kept in a continuous state of good repair and operation so as to ensure the health, comfort, safety, and well-23 

being of the residents and so as not to impede in any manner the habilitation programs of the residents; 24 

(c) the physical facilities must meet all fire and safety standards established by the state and 25 

locality. In addition, the facility must meet the provisions of the life safety code of the national fire protection 26 

association that are applicable to it. 27 

(d) there must be special facilities for nonambulatory residents to ensure their safety and comfort, 28 



 
****   
68th Legislature 2023   SB 458.1 

 

 - 47 -  Authorized Print Version – SB 458  
 
 

including special fittings on toilets and wheelchairs. Appropriate provision must be made to permit 1 

nonambulatory residents to communicate their needs to staff. 2 

(9) Residents have a right to receive prompt and adequate medical treatment for any physical or 3 

mental ailments or injuries or physical disabilities and for the prevention of any illness or disability. The medical 4 

treatment must meet standards of medical practice in the community. However, nothing in this subsection may 5 

be interpreted to impair other rights of a resident in regard to involuntary commitment for mental illness, use of 6 

psychotropic medication, use of hazardous, aversive, or experimental procedures, or the refusal of treatment. 7 

(10) Corporal punishment is not permitted. 8 

(11) The opportunity for religious worship must be accorded to each resident who desires worship. 9 

Provisions for religious worship must be made available to all residents on a nondiscriminatory basis. An 10 

individual may not be compelled to engage in any religious activities. 11 

(12) Residents have a right to a nourishing, well-balanced diet. The diet for residents must provide 12 

at a minimum the recommended daily dietary allowance as developed by the national academy of sciences. 13 

Provisions must be made for special therapeutic diets and for substitutes at the request of the resident, the 14 

resident's parents, guardian, or next of kin, or the responsible person appointed by the court in accordance with 15 

the religious requirements of any resident's faith. Denial of a nutritionally adequate diet may not be used as 16 

punishment. 17 

(13) Residents have a right to regular physical exercise several times a week. It is the duty of the 18 

facility to provide both indoor and outdoor facilities and equipment for exercise. Residents have a right to be 19 

outdoors daily in the absence of contrary medical considerations. 20 

(14) Residents have a right, under appropriate supervision, to suitable opportunities for the 21 

interaction with members of the opposite sex, as defined in 1-1-201, except when the individual treatment 22 

planning team or the qualified intellectual disability professional responsible for the formulation of a particular 23 

resident's habilitation plan writes an order to the contrary and explains the reasons for the order. The order 24 

must be renewed monthly if the restriction is to be continued." 25 

 26 

Section 36. Section 53-21-121, MCA, is amended to read: 27 

"53-21-121. Petition for commitment -- contents of -- notice of. (1) The county attorney, upon the 28 



 
****   
68th Legislature 2023   SB 458.1 

 

 - 48 -  Authorized Print Version – SB 458  
 
 

written request of any person having direct knowledge of the facts, may file a petition with the court alleging that 1 

there is a person within the county who is suffering from a mental disorder and who requires commitment 2 

pursuant to this chapter. 3 

(2) The petition must contain: 4 

(a) the name and address of the person requesting the petition and the person's interest in the 5 

case; 6 

(b) the name of the respondent and, if known, the address, age, sex, as defined in 1-1-201, marital 7 

status, and occupation of the respondent; 8 

(c) the purported facts supporting the allegation of mental disorder, including a report by a mental 9 

health professional if any, a statement of the disposition sought pursuant to 53-21-127, and the need for 10 

commitment; 11 

(d) the name and address of every person known or believed to be legally responsible for the care, 12 

support, and maintenance of the respondent for whom evaluation is sought; 13 

(e) the name and address of the respondent's next of kin to the extent known to the county 14 

attorney and the person requesting the petition; 15 

(f) the name and address of any person whom the county attorney believes might be willing and 16 

able to be appointed as friend of respondent; 17 

(g) the name, address, and telephone number of the attorney, if any, who has most recently 18 

represented the respondent for whom evaluation is sought; if there is no attorney, there must be a statement as 19 

to whether to the best knowledge of the person requesting the petition the respondent for whom evaluation is 20 

sought is indigent and unable to afford the services of an attorney; 21 

(h) a statement of the rights of the respondent, which must be in conspicuous print and identified 22 

by a suitable heading; and 23 

(i) the name and address of the mental health facility to which it is proposed that the respondent 24 

may be committed, if known. 25 

(3) Notice of the petition must be hand-delivered to the respondent and to the respondent's 26 

counsel on or before the initial appearance of the respondent before the judge or justice of the peace. The 27 

respondent's counsel shall meet with the respondent, explain the substance of the petition, and explain the 28 



 
****   
68th Legislature 2023   SB 458.1 

 

 - 49 -  Authorized Print Version – SB 458  
 
 

probable course of the proceedings. Notice of the petition and the order setting the date and time of the hearing 1 

and the names of the respondent's counsel, professional person, and friend of respondent must be hand-2 

delivered, mailed, or sent by a facsimile transmission to the person or persons legally responsible for care, 3 

support, and maintenance of the respondent, the next of kin identified in the petition, any other person identified 4 

by the county attorney as a possible friend of respondent other than the one named as the friend of respondent, 5 

the director of the department or the director's designee, and the mental health facility to which the respondent 6 

may be committed, if known. The notice may provide, other than as to the respondent and the respondent's 7 

counsel, that no further notice will be given unless written request is filed with the clerk of court." 8 

 9 

Section 37. Section 53-21-142, MCA, is amended to read: 10 

"53-21-142. Rights of persons admitted to facility. Patients admitted to a mental health facility, 11 

whether voluntarily or involuntarily, have the following rights: 12 

(1) Patients have a right to privacy and dignity. 13 

(2) Patients have a right to the least restrictive conditions necessary to achieve the purposes of 14 

commitment. Patients must be accorded the right to appropriate treatment and related services in a setting and 15 

under conditions that: 16 

(a) are the most supportive of the patient's personal liberty; and 17 

(b) restrict the patient's liberty only to the extent necessary and consistent with the patient's 18 

treatment need, applicable requirements of law, and judicial orders. 19 

(3) Patients have rights to visitation and reasonable access to telephone communications, 20 

including the right to converse with others privately, except to the extent that the professional person 21 

responsible for formulation of a particular patient's treatment plan writes an order imposing special restrictions. 22 

The written order must be renewed after each periodic review of the treatment plan if any restrictions are to be 23 

continued. Patients have an unrestricted right to visitation with attorneys, with spiritual counselors, and with 24 

private physicians and other professional persons. 25 

(4) Patients have an unrestricted right to send sealed mail. Patients have an unrestricted right to 26 

receive sealed mail from their attorneys, private physicians and other professional persons, the mental 27 

disabilities board of visitors, courts, and government officials. Patients have a right to receive sealed mail from 28 



 
****   
68th Legislature 2023   SB 458.1 

 

 - 50 -  Authorized Print Version – SB 458  
 
 

others except to the extent that a professional person responsible for formulation of a particular patient's 1 

treatment plan writes an order imposing special restrictions on receipt of sealed mail. The written order must be 2 

renewed after each periodic review of the treatment plan if any restrictions are to be continued. 3 

(5) Patients have an unrestricted right to have access to letter-writing materials, including postage, 4 

and have a right to have staff members of the facility assist persons who are unable to write, prepare, and mail 5 

correspondence. 6 

(6) Patients have a right to wear their own clothes and to keep and use their own personal 7 

possessions, including toilet articles, except to the extent that clothes or personal possessions may be 8 

determined by a professional person in charge of the patient's treatment plan to be dangerous or otherwise 9 

inappropriate to the treatment regimen. The facility has an obligation to supply an adequate allowance of 10 

clothing to any patients who do not have suitable clothing of their own. Patients must have the opportunity to 11 

select from various types of neat, clean, and seasonable clothing. The clothing must be considered the patient's 12 

throughout the patient's stay at the facility. The facility shall make provision for the laundering of patient 13 

clothing. 14 

(7) Patients have the right to keep and be allowed to spend a reasonable sum of their own money. 15 

(8) Patients have the right to religious worship. Provisions for worship must be made available to 16 

all patients on a nondiscriminatory basis. An individual may not be required to engage in any religious activities. 17 

(9) Patients have a right to regular physical exercise several times a week. The facility shall 18 

provide facilities and equipment for physical exercise. Patients have a right to be outdoors at regular and 19 

frequent intervals in the absence of contrary medical considerations. 20 

(10) Patients have the right to be provided, with adequate supervision, suitable opportunities for 21 

interaction with members of the opposite sex, as defined in 1-1-201, except to the extent that a professional 22 

person in charge of the patient's treatment plan writes an order stating that the interaction is inappropriate to the 23 

treatment regimen. 24 

(11) Patients have a right to receive prompt and adequate medical treatment for any physical 25 

ailments. In providing medical care, the mental health facility shall take advantage of whatever community-26 

based facilities are appropriate and available and shall coordinate the patient's treatment for mental illness with 27 

the patient's medical treatment. 28 



 
****   
68th Legislature 2023   SB 458.1 

 

 - 51 -  Authorized Print Version – SB 458  
 
 

(12) Patients have a right to a diet that will provide at a minimum the recommended daily dietary 1 

allowances as developed by the national academy of sciences. Provisions must be made for special 2 

therapeutic diets and for substitutes at the request of the patient or the friend of respondent in accordance with 3 

the religious requirements of any patient's faith. Denial of a nutritionally adequate diet may not be used as 4 

punishment. 5 

(13) Patients have a right to a humane psychological and physical environment within the mental 6 

health facilities. These facilities must be designed to afford patients with comfort and safety, promote dignity, 7 

and ensure privacy. The facilities must be designed to make a positive contribution to the efficient attainment of 8 

the treatment goals set for the patient. In order to ensure the accomplishment of this goal: 9 

(a) regular housekeeping and maintenance procedures that will ensure that the facility is 10 

maintained in a safe, clean, and attractive condition must be developed and implemented; 11 

(b) there must be special provision made for geriatric and other nonambulatory patients to ensure 12 

their safety and comfort, including special fittings on toilets and wheelchairs. Appropriate provision must be 13 

made to permit nonambulatory patients to communicate their needs to the facility staff. 14 

(c) pursuant to an established routine maintenance and repair program, the physical plant of each 15 

facility must be kept in a continuous state of good repair and operation in accordance with the needs of the 16 

health, comfort, safety, and well-being of the patients; 17 

(d) each facility must meet all fire and safety standards established by the state and locality. In 18 

addition, any hospital must meet the provisions of the life safety code of the national fire protection association 19 

that are applicable to hospitals. A hospital must meet all standards established by the state for general 20 

hospitals to the extent that they are relevant to psychiatric facilities. 21 

(14) A patient at a facility has the right: 22 

(a) to be informed of the rights described in this section at the time of admission and periodically 23 

after admission in language and terms appropriate to the patient's condition and ability to understand; 24 

(b) to assert grievances with respect to infringement of the rights described in this section, 25 

including the right to have a grievance considered in a fair and timely manner according to an impartial 26 

grievance procedure that must be provided for by the facility; and 27 

(c) to exercise the rights described in this section without reprisal and may not be denied 28 



 
****   
68th Legislature 2023   SB 458.1 

 

 - 52 -  Authorized Print Version – SB 458  
 
 

admission to the facility as reprisal for the exercise of the rights described in this section. 1 

(15) In order to assist a person admitted to a program or facility in the exercise or protection of the 2 

patient's rights, the patient's attorney, advocate, or legal representatives must be given reasonable access to: 3 

(a) the patient; 4 

(b) the program or facility areas where the patient has received treatment or has resided or the 5 

areas to which the patient has had access; and 6 

(c) pursuant to the written authorization of the patient, records and information pertaining to the 7 

patient's diagnosis, treatment, and related services. 8 

(16) A person admitted to a facility must be given access to any available individual or service that 9 

provides advocacy for the protection of the person's rights and that assists the person in understanding, 10 

exercising, and protecting the person's rights as described in this section. 11 

(17) This section may not: 12 

(a) obligate a professional person to administer treatment contrary to the professional's clinical 13 

judgment; 14 

(b) prevent a facility from discharging a patient for whom appropriate treatment, consistent with the 15 

clinical judgment of a professional person responsible for the patient's treatment, is or has become impossible 16 

to administer because of the patient's refusal to consent to the treatment; 17 

(c) require a facility to admit a person who has, on prior occasions, repeatedly withheld consent to 18 

appropriate treatment; or 19 

(d) obligate a facility to treat a person admitted to the facility solely for diagnostic evaluation." 20 

 21

color, sex, as defined in 1-1-201, culture, social origin or condition, or political or religious ideas. 1

Section 39. Section 60-5-522, MCA, is amended to read: 9

business, service, or activity: 12

business; 15 

(ii) provide an acceptable level of service to the public; 16 

(iii) be in continuous operation at least 8 hours a day, 5 days a week, including Saturday or 17 

Sunday; and 18 

(iv) have a telephone and restroom facilities available for public use. 19 

(b) Recreation services must: 20 

(i) be licensed and approved by state and local agencies as required by law; 21 

(ii) provide to families and the public activities of interest in which people participate for purposes 22 

of physical exercise, collective amusement, or enjoyment of nature. Such activities may include hiking, golfing, 23 

skiing, boating, swimming, picnicking, fishing, and horseback riding. 24 

(c) Tourist services must: 25 

(i) be licensed as required by law; 26 

(ii) be open to the public at least 8 hours a day, 5 days a week, including Saturday or Sunday, 27 

during the normal tourist season; and 28 



 
****   
68th Legislature 2023   SB 458.1 

 

 - 54 -  Authorized Print Version – SB 458  
 
 

(iii) provide a natural, recreational, historical, cultural, educational, or entertainment activity or a 1 

unique or unusual commercial or nonprofit activity, from which the major portion of income or visitors is derived 2 

during normal business seasons from motorists not residing in the immediate area of the activity. 3 

(2) Priority under subsection (1)(a) must be given to businesses that are in continuous operation 4

driver's license, commercial driver's license, or state identification card. If under 18 years of age but at least 15 1

Section 41. Section 72-1-103, MCA, is amended to read: 7 

"72-1-103. General definitions. Subject to additional definitions contained in the subsequent 8 

chapters that are applicable to specific chapters, parts, or sections and unless the context otherwise requires, in 9 

chapters 1 through 6, the following definitions apply: 10 

(1) "Agent" includes an attorney-in-fact under a durable or nondurable power of attorney, an 11 

individual authorized to make decisions concerning another's health care, and an individual authorized to make 12 

decisions for another under a natural death act. 13 

(2) "Application" means a written request to the clerk for an order of informal probate or 14 

appointment under chapter 3, part 2. 15 

(3) "Beneficiary", as it relates to: 16 

(a) a trust beneficiary, includes a person who has any present or future interest, vested or 17 

contingent, and also includes the owner of an interest by assignment or other transfer; 18 

(b) a charitable trust, includes any person entitled to enforce the trust; 19 

(c) a beneficiary of a beneficiary designation, refers to a beneficiary of: 20 

(i) an account with POD designation or a security registered in beneficiary form (TOD); or 21 

(ii) any other nonprobate transfer at death; and 22 

(d) a beneficiary designated in a governing instrument, includes a grantee of a deed, a devisee, a 23 

trust beneficiary, a beneficiary of a beneficiary designation, a donee, and a person in whose favor a power of 24 

attorney or a power held in any individual, fiduciary, or representative capacity is exercised. 25 

(4) "Beneficiary designation" refers to a governing instrument naming a beneficiary of: 26 

(a) an account with POD designation or a security registered in beneficiary form (TOD); or 27 

(b) any other nonprobate transfer at death. 28 



 
****   
68th Legislature 2023   SB 458.1 

 

 - 57 -  Authorized Print Version – SB 458  
 
 

(5) "Child" includes an individual entitled to take as a child under chapters 1 through 5 by intestate 1 

succession from the parent whose relationship is involved and excludes a person who is only a stepchild, a 2 

foster child, a grandchild, or any more remote descendant. 3 

(6) (a) "Claims", in respect to estates of decedents and protected persons, includes liabilities of the 4 

decedent or protected person, whether arising in contract, in tort, or otherwise, and liabilities of the estate that 5 

arise at or after the death of the decedent or after the appointment of a conservator, including funeral expenses 6 

and expenses of administration. 7 

(b) The term does not include estate taxes or demands or disputes regarding title of a decedent or 8 

protected person to specific assets alleged to be included in the estate. 9 

(7) "Clerk" or "clerk of court" means the clerk of the district court. 10 

(8) "Conservator" means a person who is appointed by a court to manage the estate of a protected 11 

person. 12 

(9) "Court" means the district court in this state having jurisdiction in matters relating to the affairs 13 

of decedents. 14 

(10) "Descendant" of an individual means all of the individual's descendants of all generations, with 15 

the relationship of parent and child at each generation being determined by the definition of child and parent 16 

contained in this code. 17 

(11) "Devise" when used as a noun means a testamentary disposition of real or personal property 18 

and when used as a verb means to dispose of real or personal property by will. 19 

(12) "Devisee" means a person designated in a will to receive a devise. For purposes of chapter 3, 20 

in the case of a devise to an existing trust or trustee or to a trustee or trust described by will, the trust or trustee 21 

is the devisee and the beneficiaries are not devisees. 22 

(13) "Disability" means cause for a protective order as described by 72-5-409. 23 

(14) "Distributee" means any person who has received property of a decedent from the decedent's 24 

personal representative other than as a creditor or purchaser. A testamentary trustee is a distributee only to the 25 

extent of distributed assets or increment to distributed assets remaining in the trustee's hands. A beneficiary of 26 

a testamentary trust to whom the trustee has distributed property received from a personal representative is a 27 

distributee of the personal representative. For purposes of this provision, "testamentary trustee" includes a 28 



 
****   
68th Legislature 2023   SB 458.1 

 

 - 58 -  Authorized Print Version – SB 458  
 
 

trustee to whom assets are transferred by will, to the extent of the devised assets. 1 

(15) "Estate" includes the property of the decedent, trust, or other person whose affairs are subject 2 

to chapters 1 through 5 as originally constituted and as it exists from time to time during administration. 3 

(16) "Exempt property" means that property of a decedent's estate that is described in 72-2-413. 4 

(17) "Fiduciary" includes a personal representative, guardian, conservator, and trustee. 5 

(18) "Foreign personal representative" means a personal representative appointed by another 6 

jurisdiction. 7 

(19) "Formal proceedings" means proceedings conducted before a judge with notice to interested 8 

persons. 9 

(20) "Governing instrument" means a deed; will; trust; insurance or annuity policy; account with 10 

POD designation; security registered in beneficiary form (TOD); pension, profit-sharing, retirement, or similar 11 

benefit plan; instrument creating or exercising a power of appointment or a power of attorney; or dispositive, 12 

appointive, or nominative instrument of any similar type. 13 

(21) "Guardian" means a person who has qualified as a guardian of a minor or incapacitated person 14 

pursuant to testamentary or court appointment but excludes one who is merely a guardian ad litem. 15 

(22) "Heirs", except as controlled by 72-2-721, means persons, including the surviving spouse and 16 

the state, who are entitled under the statutes of intestate succession to the property of a decedent. 17 

(23) "Incapacitated person" has the meaning provided in 72-5-101. 18 

(24) "Informal proceedings" means proceedings conducted without notice to interested persons by 19 

the clerk of court for probate of a will or appointment of a personal representative. 20 

(25) "Interested person" includes heirs, devisees, children, spouses, creditors, beneficiaries, and 21 

any others having a property right in or claim against a trust estate or the estate of a decedent, ward, or 22 

protected person. The term also includes persons having priority for appointment as personal representative 23 

and other fiduciaries representing interested persons. The meaning as it relates to particular persons may vary 24 

from time to time and must be determined according to the particular purposes of and matter involved in any 25 

proceeding. 26 

(26) "Issue" of a person means a descendant. 27

circumstances that entitle one or more to the whole of the property on the death of the other or others but 1

(28) "Lease" includes an oil, gas, coal, or other mineral lease. 4

association, government or governmental subdivision or agency, or any other legal or commercial entity. 13

or subdivision, or any other person authorized or obligated by law or a governing instrument to make payments. 18

anything that may be the subject of ownership. 26

(43) "Record" means information that is inscribed on a tangible medium or that is stored in an 1

another individual, nor is considered to have predeceased an event under 72-2-114 or 72-2-712. The term 23 

includes its derivatives, such as "survives", "survived", "survivor", and "surviving". 24 

(53) "Testacy proceeding" means a proceeding to establish a will or determine intestacy. 25 

(54) "Testator" includes an individual of either sex, as defined in 1-1-201. 26

trust is to be administered in the manner of an express trust. The term excludes other constructive trusts and 1

certificates to be issued to beneficiaries; common trust funds; voting trusts; security arrangements; liquidation 4

2023 -- S 0391 
======== 
LC001518 
======== 

S T A T E   O F   R H O D E   I S L A N D  

IN GENERAL ASSEMBLY 

JANUARY SESSION, A.D. 2023 

____________ 

 

A N   A C T 

RELATING TO EDUCATION -- FAIRNESS IN WOMEN'S SPORTS ACT 

Introduced By: Senator E Morgan 

Date Introduced: February 16, 2023 

Referred To: Senate Judiciary 

 

 
It is enacted by the General Assembly as follows: 

SECTION 1. The general assembly hereby finds that: 1 

(1) There are "inherent differences between men and women," and that these differences 2 

"remain cause for celebration, but not for denigration of the members of either sex or for artificial 3 

constraints on an individual's opportunity," United States v. Virginia, 518 U.S. 515, 533 (1996); 4 

(2) These "inherent differences" range from chromosomal and hormonal differences to 5 

physiological differences; 6 

(3) Men generally have "denser, stronger bones, tendons, and ligaments" and "larger hearts, 7 

greater lung volume per body mass, a higher red blood cell count, and higher hemoglobin," Neel 8 

Burton, The Battle of the Sexes, Psychology Today (July 2, 2012); 9 

(4) Men also have higher natural levels of testosterone, which affects traits such as 10 

hemoglobin levels, body fat content, the storage and use of carbohydrates, and the development of 11 

type 2 muscle fibers, all of which result in men being able to generate higher speed and power 12 

during physical activity, Doriane Lambelet Coleman, Sex in Sport, Law and Contemporary 13 

Problems 63, 74 (2017) (quoting Gina Kolata, Men, Women and Speed. 2 Words: Got 14 

Testosterone?, N.Y. Times (Aug. 21, 2008)); 15 

(5) The biological differences between females and males, especially as it relates to natural 16 

levels of testosterone, "explain the male and female secondary sex characteristics which develop 17 

during puberty and have lifelong effects, including those most important for success in sport: 18 

categorically different strength, speed, and endurance," Doriane Lambelet Coleman and Wickliffe 19 



 

 
 

LC001518 - Page 2 of 5 

Shreve, "Comparing Athletic Performances: The Best Elite Women to Boys and Men," Duke Law 1 

Center for Sports Law and Policy; 2 

(6) While classifications based on sex are generally disfavored, the Supreme Court has 3 

recognized that "sex classifications may be used to compensate women for particular economic 4 

disabilities [they have] suffered, to promote equal employment opportunity, [and] to advance full 5 

development of the talent and capacities of our Nation's people," United States v. Virginia, 518 6 

U.S. 515, 533 (1996); 7 

(7) One place where sex classifications allow for the "full development of the talent and 8 

capacities of our Nation's people" is in the context of sports and athletics; 9 

(8) Courts have recognized that the inherent, physiological differences between males and 10 

females result in different athletic capabilities. See e.g. Kleczek v. Rhode Island Interscholastic 11 

League, Inc., 612 A.2d 734, 738 (R.I. 1992) ("Because of innate physiological differences, boys 12 

and girls are not similarly situated as they enter athletic competition.");Petrie v. Ill. High Sch. Ass'n, 13 

394 N.E.2d 855, 861 (Ill. App. Ct. 1979) (noting that "high school boys [generally possess 14 

physiological advantages over] their girl counterparts" and that those advantages give them an 15 

unfair lead over girls in some sports like "high school track"); 16 

(9) A recent study of female and male Olympic performances since 1983 found that, 17 

although athletes from both sexes improved over the time span, the "gender gap" between female 18 

and male performances remained stable. "These suggest that women's performances at the high 19 

level will never match those of men." Valerie Thibault et al., Women and men in sport performance: 20 

The gender gap has not evolved since 1983, 9 Journal of Sports Science and Medicine 214, 219 21 

(2010); 22 

(10) As Duke law professor and All-American track athlete Doriane Coleman, tennis 23 

champion Martina Navratilova, and Olympic track gold medalist Sanya Richards-Ross recently 24 

wrote: "The evidence is unequivocal that starting in puberty, in every sport except sailing, shooting, 25 

and riding, there will always be significant numbers of boys and men who would beat the best girls 26 

and women in head-to-head competition. Claims to the contrary are simply a denial of science," 27 

Doriane Coleman, Martina Navratilova, et al., Pass the Equality Act, But Don't Abandon Title IX, 28 

Washington Post (Apr. 29, 2019); 29 

(11) The benefits that natural testosterone provides to male athletes is not diminished 30 

through the use of puberty blockers and cross-sex hormones. A recent study on the impact of such 31 

treatments found that even "after twelve (12) months of hormonal therapy," a man who identifies 32 

as a woman and is taking cross-sex hormones "had an absolute advantage" over female athletes and 33 

"will still likely have performance benefits" over women, Tommy Lundberg et al., "Muscle 34 



 

 
 

LC001518 - Page 3 of 5 

strength, size and composition following twelve (12) months of gender-affirming treatment in 1 

transgender individuals: retained advantage for the transwomen," Karolinksa Institutet (Sept. 26, 2 

2019); and 3 

(12) Having separate sex-specific teams furthers efforts to promote sex equality. Sex-4 

specific teams accomplish this by providing opportunities for female athletes to demonstrate their 5 

skill, strength, and athletic abilities while also providing them with opportunities to obtain 6 

recognition and accolades, college scholarships, and the numerous other long-term benefits that 7 

flow from success in athletic endeavors. 8 

SECTION 2. Title 16 of the General Laws entitled "EDUCATION" is hereby amended by 9 

adding thereto the following chapter: 10 

CHAPTER 112  11 

FAIRNESS IN WOMEN'S SPORTS ACT 12 

16-112-1. Short title.  13 

This chapter shall be known and may be cited as the "Fairness in Women's Sports Act". 14 

16-112-2. Designation of athletic teams. 15 

Interscholastic, intercollegiate, intramural, or club athletic teams or sports that are 16 

sponsored by a public school or any public school district activities association or a public 17 

institution of higher education or any higher education institution that is a member of the national 18 

collegiate athletic association (NCAA), national association of intercollegiate athletics (NAIA), or 19 

national junior college athletic association (NJCAA) shall be expressly designated as one of the 20 

following based on biological sex: 21 

(1) Males, men, or boys; 22 

(2) Females, women, or girls; or 23 

(3) Coed or mixed. 24 

(i) Athletic teams or sports designated for females, women, or girls shall not be open to 25 

students of the male sex. 26 

(ii) If disputed, a student may establish sex by presenting a signed physician's statement 27 

that shall indicate the student's sex based solely on: 28 

(A) The student's internal and external reproductive anatomy; 29 

(B) The student's normal endogenously produced levels of testosterone; and 30 

(C) An analysis of the student's genetic makeup. 31 

16-112-3. Protection for educational institutions.   32 

A government entity, any licensing or accrediting organization, or any athletic association 33 

or organization shall not entertain a complaint, open an investigation, or take any other adverse 34 



 

 
 

LC001518 - Page 4 of 5 

action against a school or an institution of higher education for maintaining separate interscholastic, 1 

intercollegiate, intramural, or club athletic teams or sports for students of the female sex. 2 

16-112-4. Cause of action. 3 

(a) Any student who is deprived of an athletic opportunity or suffers any direct or indirect 4 

harm as a result of a violation of this chapter shall have a private cause of action for injunctive 5 

relief, damages, and any other relief available under law against the school or institution of higher 6 

education. 7 

(b) Any student who is subject to retaliation or other adverse action by a school, institution 8 

of higher education, or athletic association or organization as a result of reporting a violation of this 9 

chapter to an employee or representative of the school, institution, or athletic association or 10 

organization, or to any state or federal agency with oversight of schools or institutions of higher 11 

education in the state, shall have a private cause of action for injunctive relief, damages, and any 12 

other relief available under law against the school, institution, or athletic association or 13 

organization. 14 

(c) Any school or institution of higher education that suffers any direct or indirect harm as 15 

a result of a violation of this chapter shall have a private cause of action for injunctive relief, 16 

damages, and any other relief available under law against the government entity, licensing or 17 

accrediting organization, or athletic association or organization. 18 

(d) All civil actions shall be initiated within two (2) years after the harm occurred. Persons 19 

or organizations who prevail on a claim brought pursuant to this section shall be entitled to 20 

monetary damages, including for any psychological, emotional, and physical harm suffered, 21 

reasonable attorneys' fees and costs, and any other appropriate relief. 22 

16-112-5. Severability.  23 

The provisions of this chapter are hereby declared to be severable and if any provision of 24 

this chapter or the application of such provision to any person or circumstance is declared invalid 25 

for any reason, such declaration shall not affect the validity of the remaining portions of this 26 

chapter. 27 

SECTION 3. This act shall take effect January 1, 2024.  28 

======== 
LC001518 
========



 

 
 

LC001518 - Page 5 of 5 

EXPLANATION 

BY THE LEGISLATIVE COUNCIL 

OF 

A N   A C T 

RELATING TO EDUCATION -- FAIRNESS IN WOMEN'S SPORTS ACT 

***

This act would categorize women by their biological identity at birth rather than their 1 

gender identity for purpose of organized sports. A team would be categorized as males, men, or 2 

boys; females, women, or girls; or coed or mixed. If there is a dispute, a student would establish 3 

sex by presenting a signed physician's statement that shall indicate the student's sex. Additionally, 4 

this act would create a cause of action for any student who is deprived of an athletic opportunity or 5 

subject to retaliation as a result of violations of this chapter. 6 

This act would take effect January 1, 2024.  7 

======== 
LC001518 
========
